statements.statement: University administrators need to protect free speech and peaceful protest, but they also have a responsibility to keep campuses safe and make sure no group feels threatened or harassed. I think they should set and enforce clear rules: demonstrations are fine as long as they don’t turn into intimidation, block people from getting to class, or disrupt the basic mission of education.

statements.statement: University administrators should keep strict order on campus and not allow protests to disrupt classes, threaten students, or damage property, no matter which side of the Israel/Gaza conflict the protesters support. They must enforce the rules evenly, protect Jewish and Muslim students alike from intimidation, and make it clear that calls for violence or harassment are not “free speech.” Universities are supposed to be places to study and learn, not training grounds for mobs.

statements.statement: As someone who works in healthcare and sees daily how conflict and trauma affect people, I think university administrators need to protect both students’ safety and their right to speak out, even when the topic is as charged as Israel and Gaza. They should set clear, consistently enforced rules against harassment or violence, while still allowing peaceful protest and open discussion from all sides. I’d also like to see campuses invest in facilitated dialogue and education on the history and human impact of the conflict so students are encouraged to engage thoughtfully, not just emotionally.

statements.statement: As someone who values both justice and order, I think campus administrators should protect students’ right to protest on Israel/Gaza while drawing a firm line at harassment, threats, or discrimination against any group. They should create clear, consistently enforced rules for demonstrations, provide balanced educational forums with diverse speakers, and make sure Muslim, Jewish, Arab, and Palestinian students all feel physically safe and respected.

statements.statement: University administrators need to keep order first and foremost—protect students’ safety, prevent property damage, and enforce the rules the same way for everyone. Peaceful protest is fine, but the moment it turns into harassment, threats, or occupations of buildings, it’s time to step in firmly and, if necessary, involve law enforcement. They should stay neutral politically, make it clear that intimidation of Jewish or Muslim students won’t be tolerated, and remember that a university is a place for learning, not for letting chaos take over.

statements.statement: As someone who’s pretty liberal and values open dialogue, I think university administrators should protect students’ rights to protest and speak out on Israel/Gaza, while setting clear, consistent rules against harassment, doxxing, and violence for all sides. Campuses should create structured spaces—like moderated forums or teach-ins—where students can actually learn the history and hear multiple perspectives, not just shout past each other. And they need to be transparent and even-handed in enforcing policies so that no group feels targeted or silenced just because their stance is unpopular.

statements.statement: University administrators should protect students’ rights to peaceful protest and free expression, while drawing a firm line against harassment, intimidation, and any form of violence or hate speech. They need to create clear, consistently enforced policies that apply to all groups, communicate transparently about safety and campus rules, and make space for structured dialogue where people with very different views can speak and listen. As a parent and a Christian, I’d want campuses to be places where students can wrestle with hard issues like Israel/Gaza honestly and passionately, but also learn to see the humanity in those who disagree with them.

statements.statement: As a retired teacher and a Catholic who believes in both human dignity and open dialogue, I think university administrators should protect students’ rights to peaceful protest while drawing a firm line at harassment, intimidation, or disruption of learning. They should create structured forums for education and dialogue—bringing in historians, ethicists, and people with diverse perspectives—so that emotion is balanced with facts and empathy. It’s also important that policies are applied consistently to all groups, and that leaders speak clearly against antisemitism, Islamophobia, and any dehumanizing rhetoric, while still encouraging students to stay engaged and morally awake.

statements.statement: As someone who’s lived through a long stretch of history and seen what happens when people are silenced, I believe university administrators must protect students’ rights to protest and speak out on Israel and Gaza, while drawing a very firm line at harassment, threats, and discrimination of any kind. They should create structured, well-facilitated spaces for dialogue, ensure the safety of Jewish, Muslim, Arab, and all other students, and resist political pressure to shut down peaceful demonstrations just because the views expressed are controversial or unpopular.

statements.statement: I think university administrators should let students protest about Israel and Gaza as long as it stays peaceful and people aren’t threatening or hurting each other. Everyone should be able to express their views and stand up for what they believe, but the school also has to make sure no group feels unsafe or targeted because of their religion or background.
